settings.text: We spoke to co-founder of Wardrobe ICONS and mother of two, Laura Fantacci, about how she is embracing simple pleasures during life in lockdown. From finding more time for herself via feelgood wellbeing rituals to cooking from scratch each evening, discover how she’s striking the work / life balance from home.

settings.grid-content:
How have you and the Wardrobe Icons team adjusted to working from home?

Being Italian, I felt like I had a frightening eye into the future with all of this, so we used our initiative to work from home early on. The whole Wardrobe ICONS team is working remotely and being very productive. We have a meeting every morning on Google Hangouts which provides a nice moment for some human contact.

As a team, we are all trying to stay positive and see the work that we do as a helpful tool for our readers, to provide a distraction, and to think about the future in a positive way. At the beginning, it was hard to look at fashion as something vital, but as time has gone on I have thought about how it has always provided a type of escapism, whether it’s buying a dress for a holiday that you’re hoping to go on soon enough, or a pair of new slippers that make you feel more pulled together at home. These are things that help the mind as well and that is what is so important right now.

settings.title: What’s the best thing about being design director at Chinti & Parker?
settings.text: I love working in a female founded, female director led company. I have a great team around me and it’s nice to be able to have real impact on the brand. I was drawn to all of these things and the way that things are done consciously and with quality. It’s a brand that can do very chic and understated as well as colourful and fun which allows a really interesting opportunity to be creative and make beautiful product.

settings.title: How would you describe the Chinti & Parker woman?
settings.text: She’s me! And also, my friends. She’s like every member of our office, to be honest. The customer is diverse and there is something in the collection for everyone. From the cashmere neutrals in essentials to the more vibrant pieces that express fun and personality.
“As a team, we are all trying to stay positive and see the work that we do as a helpful tool for our readers, to provide a distraction, and to think about the future in a positive way.”

settings.grid-content:
Are you still making an effort every day with how you dress?

Absolutely, I have made a little bit of a point of getting dressed up every day. I have always dressed up for myself, but also for other women, because there is a connection that comes from wearing something pretty and then someone complimenting you. When that is taken away, and you are just doing it for yourself, it is a very interesting exercise. Wearing something that makes me feel comfortably put together is an absolute priority and I strongly recommend it, otherwise your day doesn’t have the same structure. I think if you stay in your pyjamas all day, it can set you back in creating a seemingly normal routine.

settings.title: What advice would you give to someone in a creative rut?
settings.text: You can’t force it. It’s really difficult to always remain your most creative when it’s your job and you need to channel it constantly, whilst also picking up on the unavoidable day to day aspects that are less creative, and more admin based. You are constantly switching your brain from one thing to the other. Because I work in fashion, if I want to be inspired, I have to step away from it. My advice is to read a book, see an exhibition, watch an inspiring film or just get out of your routine and have a change of scenery. As a designer, there are always times when you don’t know how you are going to find the inspiration for the next season, but it always comes together in the end.

How else have you kept some routine in your days?

I have had to rethink my routine a little to put me and my wellbeing at the centre of it. I have two little girls, aged 3 and 7, so of course my routine has to align with their needs as well. In the morning, things have remained virtually unchanged, I spend some time getting ready, simply washing and moisturising my face, doing my hair and then getting dressed. I will have breakfast with the kids, and then the working day begins. I always stop for a nice healthy lunch; I think it is important that we take that time off. My evenings have changed because they are usually much more frantic with homework and having two kids to bath, but it has all kind of relaxed a little bit.

settings.grid-content:
How do you like to spend your evenings and weekends at the moment?

I have taken up doing yoga every night with my sister, who is living with us. The breathing and the asanas really help me to unwind. My working days are quite full on, and trying to make sure I come out of this period with the business intact is a huge responsibility, so taking that time for myself in the evening is important. After yoga, I lock myself in the bathroom, take a shower and maybe do a body scrub or put a mask on. We then cook dinner from scratch every evening; I like to lay the table nicely and really make an effort. I try not to work after dinner, and I don’t watch television as I prefer to go to bed with a good book.

On a Friday evening I pretty much switch off from work except for overseeing our social channels. Weekends are all about family meals, and spending time with the girls. One of my other top priorities is catching up with friends and family around the world. I am finding that there are some silver linings to all of this – rethinking your life, your rhythm and what your essentials are, and catering to those.

settings.title: Laura’s Must-Haves
settings.text:
Reading

I have just finished reading The Fabulous Bouvier Sisters by Nancy Schoenberger and Sam Kashner. It’s about Jackie Kennedy and Lee Radziwill, and was a fascinating albeit sad read because of their tragic lives. I am now reading Lunch with the FT: A Second Helping by Lionel Barber which I love because each interview is so different


Listening

I have been relistening to a few episodes of our own podcast, ICONversations, where we talk with amazing women such as Jasmine Hemsley about rituals; Elizabeth Saltzman about confidence; and more recently our Editor at Large, Deborah Brett, about perfection.


Beautifying

I find De Mamiel’s Salvation Body Oil is lovely to use in the evening as part of my nighttime skincare routine. I am also finding that a pretty headband is helping me to feel dressed up, from the waist up!

Moving

Yoga with Adriene’s 30-day YouTube programme is a great little course and each one is less than half an hour long. I am also finding my daily walk really precious; I breathe in the fresh air, look up at the sky and really appreciate being outdoors.


Sleeping

I love to use my This Works Deep Sleep Pillow Spray to ensure a good night’s sleep. I also give myself a brief foot massage, switch my phone off, have soft yellow lights on, and read. Reading for me is essential for helping me to get to sleep.


Wearing

I love sleepwear and don’t just wear any old thing; this beautiful silk robe is perfect as part of my evening beauty regime. I also love to wear the Essentials cream cashmere set after my evening shower, when I’m not quite ready to put my pyjamas on and want to be comfortable but still wear something beautiful.
